I am a labourer, of Adam-street, Rotherhithe—the prisoner came to me as a servant about 10th April—my wife was then ill, and died on 18th April—the prisoner remained in the house till 11th May, taking care of my house, and acting as a servant—I had four children altogether—I did not know that the prisoner was going to leave, but when I came home to dinner on 11th May she was gone, and the young baby also, which was 11 weeks old—I have been in search of her ever since till 14th July, when I found her in the Gray's Inn-road—my little girl, who was with me, recognised her in the crowd, and I took her by the shoulder, and asked where my child was—she said that she came as far Leadenhall-street the same night with the baby, and fell asleep, when she awoke she had not got the child—she had no business to take it into Leadenhall-street—I have never seen the child since.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Had you known her before she came to nurse your wife? A. No—she did that to my perfect satisfaction—she had occasion to go out sometimes—I do not know whether she had taken the baby out for an airing before—my eldest little girl is getting on for 11 years old—she is not here.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. How far is Rotherhithe from Leadenhall-street? A. About two miles from the bridge—the child had on the ordinary dress of a child 11 weeks old—I also missed a shirt from my house, a black frock belonging to my eldest girl, and two pillow-cases.

CHARLES PEMBRALL (Policeman, G 101). On 24th July I was on duty in Gray's Inn-lane, and Plater gave the prisoner into my custody for stealing his child—he said she came from Rotherhithe on 11th May, sat down in Leadenhall-street that night, and fell asleep, and when she woke the child was missing.
Cross-examined. Q. Did she say she had had a drop to drink? A. Yes.

SARAH DAVIS . I get my living by ironing, about three minutes' walk from where Plater lives—I know the prisoner by sight—I was going to work one morning after the child was missed, it was the end of June or the beginning of July, and saw the prisoner with a baby in her arms in
Tooley-street—I did not speak to her—I did know the child—it was in long clothes.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know that the child was missing? A. Yes, two or three days afterwards; it was a little after 8 in the morning when I saw her in Tooley-street; I was on one side and she on the other I stood and looked at her across the street—I had not heard a word about the child being missing at this time; but I stopped and looked at her because I wondered where she was going to with the baby—I thought it was her daughter's child—I knew that her married, daughter had an infant child.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. Have you the least doubt she is the woman? A. I am quite sure.

795.
THOMAS BROWN (24)
, Stealing 8 spoons, value 6l., of
Susan Scott, in her dwelling-house; and afterwards feloniously breaking out of the same, to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months.

796.
JOHN BARKER (23)
, Embezzling the sum of 6s. 7 1/2 d., and 2s. 11d. of
John Marchant, his master, to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

797.
JANE GOODINGS (19)
, Stealing 1 vest, 2 handkerchiefs, and other articles, value 3l., of
Ann Robinson, her mistress; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .—
Confined Nine Months.

p.hi: There was another indictment against the prisoner.

div1.p:
798.
BAZILL WOODGATE (33)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
James Stevens.
NOT GUILTY .

799.
EWEN McGOWER (29)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
Joseph Lancaster.

MARY ANN FREEMAN . I am a widow, and live in Richardson-buildings, Woolwich—on 13th July, in consequence of some information I received, I went to the dead-house in Woolwich, and saw the body of a man there whom I had known twenty years; he used to go by the name of "Shefford Tom;" he enlisted in the Royal Artillery as Joseph Lancaster; he is known by that name.

ELLEN DERBAM . I am single, and live at Woolwich—on this 12th July I was at the Three Marines public-house; I left a little after 12—I was drinking with the deceased, Joseph Lancaster—we left the house together, and walked on into High-street; I there bade him good-night—soon after that the prisoner passed me; I was too far off to hear whether he spoke to Lancaster—I then heard a noise, in consequence of that I went back—I heard the prisoner ask the deceased what he was making a noise about—the deceased said, "A slap on the nose if you like"—with that they both stripped, and began fighting—the deceased made the first attempt to strike the prisoner, but missed his blow; the prisoner then butted the deceased with his head, on the lower part of his stomach—he fell down on his back, and after he was down the prisoner kicked him, somewhere about the neck—after he was knocked down I did not see him move—I only saw the prisoner kick him once; after that he went away and left the deceased on the ground—
a great number of people and a policeman came up—that was all I saw; I saw the dead body of the man at 4 o'clock in the morning.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not tell him I was a cripple, and had but one arm? A. You had your arm in a sling.
COURT. Q. Did he follow the prisoner? A. They were together when I came up—the deceased had had a little drink—he had been drinking.

Prisoner. Q. Did not I walk away, and say I would not fight? A. I do not know; you had your coat off—he might have walked after you 8 or 10 yards—I heard them talking loud—the prisoner kicked him near the neck when he was on the ground.

JOHN PETERS . I am a driver in the Royal Artillery at Woolwich—I was in High-street about half-past 12 on this morning—I saw Lancaster there lying in the road—I also saw the prisoner there—he kicked him in the face, and then walked five or six paces away—he came back again, and said, "I have got but one arm, but I will do for you," and kicked him again in the neck—he then left him on the ground, and walked away—I then went up to the deceased, and held his head up; blood was then flowing from his mouth and nose—I assisted in taking him to the station—he appeared dead at that time.
Prisoner. He was not there at all. Witness. I was there—the man was on the ground when I came up—there was a lamp close by.

WILLIAM STEWART . I am surgeon to the police force at Woolwich—I accompanied the policeman, 63, to the dead-house at Woolwich on the morning of the 14th, the next morning—my assistant saw him before that—I examined the body externally; the only external mark of violence was on the left side of the neck, where there was a bruise, and the skin slightly raised; it was below the ear, and behind the corner of the lower jaw—blood was rushing from the nostrils, but no other external violence—I began my internal examination by examining the head—I found all the vessels of the brain congealed with blood, and on the surface were large clots in two or three different places; and on opening the brain, there was a large clot on the left side—on removing the brain from the skull, there was also a very large clot of blood pressing on the spinal marrow—the result that I drew was that he died from rupture of the brain, from pressure on the brain, and apoplexy—it might be the result of a blow or a fall on the ground—the vessels would rupture, the blood would be effused, and death would ensue from pressure on the brain—if a person had been drinking, and had received a blow in the stomach, and had fallen down on the ground, it would be very likely to bring death.

COURT. Q. From the pressure of this blood on the brain, would it find its way through the nose and mouth? A. No—probably some of the vessels in the upper part of the nostril had received a blow—I don't think a blow on the ear would occasion the death of a man.

EDWARD FEATHERSTONE (Policeman, R 63). I was on duty in High-street, on Tuesday night, 12th July, about half-past 12—in consequence of some
thing I heard, I went to the Shamrock beershop, and there I saw the deceased lying on the ground, and a number of people standing round—after that, I went in pursuit of the prisoner, and found him in a small cottage—he was lying outside his bed with his clothes on, apparently asleep—I took him in charge, and told him that he had assaulted a man in High-street, and kicked him—he had been drinking.
JANE CHAPMAN . I was with the prisoner on this night—the deceased man, Lancaster, came up, and charged me with taking a handkerchief—the

prisoner told him to go away, and not to make such a noise, and asked him what he wanted—he said "A slap on the mouth"—the deceased then took his coat off, and hit the prisoner twice—then the prisoner took his coat off, and threw him down—the prisoner then walked away by himself—I went towards him—I did not steal the handkerchief—the prisoner had but one arm—he knocked the deceased down with his shoulder, and tried to kick him.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going home about 12 o'clock—I walked down High-street with this young woman—the man came up, and stopped me—he asked the young woman where the handkerchief was she took—she said she had not taken it—I said she was in my company all the night—he asked me what I had to do with it, and said he would give me a slap in the mouth—I said I had but one arm; I could not fight—he then came up to me and struck me—I said, "Don't do that; I am a cripple"—I then pushed my shoulder against him, knocked him down, and walked away.

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

800.
ROBERT DUCK (18)
, Stealing 1 watch, value 3l. 3s., the property of
Eliza Ruddock, from her person.

ELLIZA RUDDOCK . I am the wife of John Ruddock, of 2, Royal-hill, Green
wich—I was there on July 22d, at half-past 6—while I was there two lads came in; One of them was the prisoner—they came for a fancy chair for their mother, they said—one took it, and the other looked at it—they got close to me; just before that I had my watch in my pocket—I then saw one of them run out, and heard my keys fall on the ground—I caught the other one by the coat, and said, "You rascal! you hare got my watch"—I caught him by the sleeve, and he slipped away—the watch was worth 3 guineas; I have never seen it since—I have the piece of ribbon that was attached to it; he caught that.

Prisoner. Q. When I came into your shop you charged me, when you caught hold of me, with stealing your watch? A. Yes—I did not say at the station that you took the watch—I don't remember that the Magistrate asked me when I saw my watch last, and I could not answer—my watch was in my pocket when you were in the shop—you did not give me my keys when they fell down.

JOHN ALLEN (Policeman, R 140). I received charge of the prisoner—I caught him just in front of the prosecutrix's house; she charged him with taking her watch—he said he wanted water; he should faint away—he did not appear in that state.
Prisoner's Defence. There is no truth proved against me; is there any gentleman of the jury who could buy a gold watch for three guineas? if there is, I wish him to stand up.
GUILTY .—He was further charged with having been before convicted.

GUILTY.—
Confined Six Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY SEPTEMBER 19TH.
